title: Quiz 3: Nutrition and Opportunistic Infections
topicName: HIV, AIDS and STIs Comprehensive Teaching Manual
description: Focuses on nutritional assessment (NACS), infant feeding, and management of common opportunistic infections.

questions.question: Which of the following are benefits of good nutrition for a person living with HIV? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Good nutrition supports the immune system, maintains weight/muscle, and helps handle medication, but it does not cure HIV.
questions.hint: Think about support and maintenance, not cure.

questions.question: The acronym NACS stands for Nutritional Assessment, ___BLANK___, and Support.
questions.explanation: NACS stands for Nutritional Assessment, Counselling, and Support.
questions.hint: It involves talking to the patient about their diet.

questions.question: Which anthropometric measurement is commonly used to assess nutritional status in adults and children?
questions.explanation: MUAC and BMI are standard anthropometric measurements used in NACS.

questions.question: Match the opportunistic infection to its description:

pairs.right: Cancer causing purple spots on skin
Lung infection causing dry cough and breathlessness
Fungal infection often affecting the brain (meningitis)

questions.explanation: KS is a vascular cancer; Candidiasis is yeast; PCP is a specific lung fungus; Cryptococcus often causes meningitis.
questions.hint: Connect the specific symptom (purple spots, thrush, meningitis) to the disease.

questions.question: Breastfeeding is not recommended for HIV-positive mothers even if they are on ART.
questions.explanation: With ART interventions, the risk of MTCT is significantly reduced, and breastfeeding is often recommended to improve infant survival, provided guidelines are followed.
questions.hint: Think about the benefits of breast milk vs. the reduced risk when on meds.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of malnutrition?
questions.explanation: Signs of malnutrition include muscle wasting, weight loss, edema (swelling), and pale skin.
questions.hint: Think about loss of body mass.

questions.question: What is the term for the accumulation of fluid in the body tissues, often seen as swelling in feet, which can be a sign of malnutrition?
questions.explanation: Edema (or Oedema) is swelling caused by fluid retention, often a sign of severe protein-energy malnutrition.
questions.hint: Starts with 'O' or 'E' and means swelling.

questions.question: Why is an HIV-infected person more at risk for malnutrition? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Reduced food intake due to anorexia
Increased metabolism due to chronic infection

questions.explanation: HIV increases energy requirements while simultaneously reducing intake (appetite loss) and absorption (diarrhea).
questions.hint: Does the body need more or less energy to fight infection?

questions.question: Which bacterium causes Tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.explanation: TB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
questions.hint: The name of the bacteria is very similar to the disease.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for defaulter tracing in the correct order:

items.text: Call treatment buddy if no response
Prioritize home visit if unreachable > 7 days

questions.explanation: The process starts with identification, moves to phone tracing (patient then buddy), recording outcome, and finally physical tracing.
